comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Wow! these were temporary structures, here you will see a version in the exact same location for a visit in 1900. Temporary gateway erected for the visit of Queen Victoria to Dublin in 1900. A ceremonial affair, the Queen was to enter the city boundaries and be given the keys to the city by the Lord Mayor and Aldermen. Described in The Irish Times as “the old city gates, a handsome representation of which is to be erected at the entrance of the municipal boundary at Leeson Street Bridge”.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: COMPLAINT I have noticed that there has been a serious Anti Canidae editorial shift over the last few weeks.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: A description of the preparations for the visit from Times (London) July 21st 1903. Of architectural decorations, of huge triumphal arches, and replicas of ancient buildings there are perhaps not so many as usual. Indeed, a model of the ancient city gate at Leeson-street-bridge is the only example of that kind of edifice. But behind these substantial and by no means alway satisfactory efforts every conceivable thing has been done, and done with haste. The very statues have been dressed and washed, and, as is notorious, the statues in Dublin are very fine. Nelson on a colossal pillar dominates Sackville-street or O'Connell-street - it bears both names in common parlance - and from Nelson to the houses on either side depend great strings of flags. Father Mathew, virgin white, stands behind Nelson, and at the other end of the street stands the huge statue of O'Connell, which was being carefully cleansed this morning. On either side of the roads were masts with interlacing festoons of parti-coloured rosettes and flags without number. ... O'Connell's bridge promises to be a glory in the way of illuminations, which the waters of the Liffey, in spite of their dull and malodourous nature, will reflect from their surface The visit was not without controversy - Dublin corporation refused to have anything to do with the visit. The Times (London) July 22nd 1903 the following day describing the procession itself: Above the city end of the bridge towered the simulacrum of the ancient city gate, and beyond it was a stand thronged with people. Here the welcome was prodigious, and for a moment those who saw it were reminded of Queen Victoria's State entry of 1900. But they were reminded of it in a very unpleasant fashion. Today, as then, the roar of cheers from the far side announced the coming of the royal guest some minutes before the head of the procession hove into sight. This time, as before, the welcome from the stands and the surrounding throng was grand and inspiring; but this time the formal civic welcome, the picturesque formal incident of the Sovereign to the metropolis of Ireland, was most lamentably conspicuous by its absence.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seal_of_the_Realm Edward VII of the United Kingdom. EDWARDVS VII D:G: BRITT: ET TERRARUM TRANSMAR: QVÆ IN DIT: SVNT BRIT: REX F:D: IND:IMP (To be read: Edwardus Septimus Dei gratiâ Britanniarum et terrarum transmarinarum quae in Ditione sunt Britannicâ, Rex, Fidei Defensor, Indiae Imperator) Edward VII, by the grace of God, of the Britains and of the lands across the sea which are in the British Dominion, King, Defender of the Faith, Emperor of India. ANN SECVNDO=In the second year of his reign Translation needed for this - EXOI TATVS ADES PORTAE PANDVNIVR AMICO PORTAE=gate or portal

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
I wonder how temporary the arch was.  Judging from the bunting visible through the arch and the flags on the buildings on the left, the photograph was taken shortly after the visit.

And seeing how the arch narrows the roadway creating a bottleneck, forcing everything onto the tramlines - presumably it got dismantled fairly soon after the visit.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I think it reads 'EXOPTATUS ADES PORTAE PANDUNTUR AMICO' which would literally mean something like 'longed-for one, you are here, the gates are opened by a friend' or more freely translated: 'We've been looking forward to seeing you, and now you're here, we open the gates in friendship'

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] London Times , July 18th, reporting the previous day (Friday - the royal visit was on Monday) ... at Leeson-street bridge, where the "ancient" gate, through which their Majesties will enter the city is rapidly taking shape... If it was stiill only 'taking shape' on Friday, it suggests it was being put up in haste, and could be dismantled equally quickly, or even quicker in a strong wind. Talking of which (July 22nd 1903): ... to the point where Leeson-street spans the canal, on the banks of which the uprooted trunks of a number of fine elms are silent witnesses of the hurricane which swept over Ireland earlier in the year ... The hurricane hit in late Feb and early March, and affected a wide area. The rain which fell was reported to be 'loaded with sand' and one vessel reported a sandstorm at sea. It also claimed the lives of six of the crew of the Mumbles lifeboat. The arch for the visit of George IV a was wood and canvas
